text: It's Mark. Nemi. And Wayne. Wayne, thanks for sitting in. Our main host, Ian Freeman, is off talking to a bunch of people who probably pretty much hate him and don't want to hear from him. He went to a city council meeting, and I guess there's something to do with the common closing it down. I don't know entirely. Whatever it is, he's playing with bureaucrats this evening. Lots of eyes on the website there. A whole bunch of visits per month. I was very, very surprised. Go to freetalklive.com. You know, Wayne, we both have the same story this evening. It's also difficult to know how that measurement's being made. Is it based on personnel? I guess shooting bad guys. Yeah, killing people. Military operations? Shooting bad guys? Shooting bad guys, sure. I mean, you know, we need to protect our diplomats over there, so we hire private contractors. But it's not the same thing as the American military. It's not troops fighting for a flag. What would you constitute protecting a nation? Nothing that's happened in the last 70 years. Exactly. Wait, I'm sorry. Nothing that has happened in the last 70 years in protecting the nation. It is, again, the SR-40C at Ruger.com. So, Buck, you there? Buck? Hello? Hey, Buck. So, Buck, it looks like a friend of yours is trying to lead us both down the Primrose path. They felt that they were, they would always be misused, that they would be used to, you know, create empire, that they would be extraordinarily expensive, that they were more dangerous to liberty than pretty much anything else except perhaps a central bank. And I would, but I would say if you're going to have one, Alexander Hamilton, you know, the sort of the early big government guy, he really wanted himself a military. And, you know, that's what happened. I would say if, in General Smedley Butler, the two-time Medal of Honor winner, actually it should have been three, he was, but at the time they wouldn't give Medals of Honor to officers. So two-time, but practically speaking, three-time Medal of Honor winner. He suggested that the military only be, the army only be kept on U.S. soil and that the Navy only be within 500 miles of the coastline. Now, I don't know if that's practical today, but I would say that the, you know, land-based military should probably be on U.S. soil and then, you know, the ships can, they can go around in the oceans wherever they want to go. Okay. That's, I don't want to insult what you said. It's pretty general there, though. Yes, you're correct. Many of the founding fathers were extraordinarily uneasy about having a standing military. I mean, Jefferson alone, I think, really epitomizes their views. Of course, you can probably empathize with them as well, considering that they had just fought a revolution against British troops that they would have once considered friendly. I mean, King George essentially sent the troops over to, as he would have seen it, enforce order in the colonies and really just collect taxes. So, to me, it's pretty understandable why some of the founding fathers, really the Republican founding fathers, would have been uneasy about having a standing military because with the executive under the Constitution having both the power of the purse and the sword, they probably just saw the military as a device that the executive could use to collect taxes. Do you think that... I think you can argue both ways, however, that the President of the United States does not use the United States military to collect taxes. I mean, clearly, the military has got a much, much more specific and larger purpose here.
